body: Can you help me understand what broke? `fontMap` was added as an optional parameter last in the list so whether you were using named or ordered parameters, I don't think any existing calls should have broken. Maybe I'm missing something on the second order effects of libraries though.

So source compatibility is maintained, for anyone that updates, nothing needs to change for compilation.

Binary compatibility however breaks for upgraded users that depend on other libraries that are already compiled against 5.2. 

Because of how kotlin compiles functions, the function signature libraries compile against in 5.2 is `LottieAnimation(a,b,c,defaultMarker)`, from 6.0 the function signature available at runtime is now `LottieAnimation(a,b,c,D,defaultMarker)` (where D is the new parameter). 

So that for any user that is upgraded to 6.0, which would cause its transitive dependencies that are pointing to version 5.2 to be upgraded to version 6.0, the latter method signature will be available at runtime but the already compiled dependencies will be "looking for" the former method signature.
Got it. I think adding `@JvmOverloads` here would generate the necessary backwards compatible bytecode. Is that correct?
@efemoney Can you confirm if `@JvmOverloads` would solve this issue?

`@JvmOverloads` depends. It would work if the previous order was somehow maintained when the new parameters were added. but its less useful for example if a parameter was added  somewhere in the middle of the arguments list. 
For methods with a lot of default parameters it'll also generate a ton of (most likely unused) overloads.
I always add new parameters as optional and at the end for this reason. Considering that most large apps have multidex and use r8, the extra methods should be stripped out of release builds.

repository.name: lottie-android
repository.description: Render After Effects animations natively on Android and iOS, Web, and React Native

issue.title: Lottie broke binary compat from 6.2.0 to 6.3.0

repository.name: lottie-android
repository.description: Render After Effects animations natively on Android and iOS, Web, and React Native

issue.body:
This is related to #2266. 

`@JvmOverloads` actually does not fix binary compatibility for composable functions (I have learned as much and even more now). To be fair it **probably** does not also fix binary compat for non-composable functions but I haven't confirmed.

The only way to maintain binary compat with top level (static) composable functions is to duplicate the method, one with the **old signature** that will call the other with the **new signature**.

Also, my recommendation would be to track binary compatibility of lottie-compose with kotlinx BCV or metalava.

issue.title: Binary incompatibility between 6.3.0 and 6.4.0

repository.name: lottie-android
repository.description: Render After Effects animations natively on Android and iOS, Web, and React Native

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
We recently updated in our app to 6.4.0 and we received crashes running from libraries compiled against 6.3.0

Here is a stacktrace from the crash
```
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: No static method LottieAnimation(Lcom/airbnb/lottie/LottieComposition;Landroidx/compose/ui/Modifier;ZZLcom/airbnb/lottie/compose/LottieClipSpec;FIZZZLcom/airbnb/lottie/RenderMode;ZZLcom/airbnb/lottie/compose/LottieDynamicProperties;Landroidx/compose/ui/Alignment;Landroidx/compose/ui/layout/ContentScale;ZZLjava/util/Map;Lcom/airbnb/lottie/AsyncUpdates;Landroidx/compose/runtime/Composer;III)V in class Lcom/airbnb/lottie/compose/LottieAnimationKt; or its super classes (declaration of 'com.airbnb.lottie.compose.LottieAnimationKt' appears in /data/app/com.careem.acma.qa-zL-fH-NABMFzbpoValaHgg==/base.apk!classes3.dex)
```

We had similar issue when we bumped from 6.2.0 to 6.3.0 but did not raise a bug.

**Steps To Reproduce**
Compile a library using Lottie 6.3.0 using `LottieAnimation` and run the code using 6.4.0 at runtime
